title: Relief of Mourners Before a Tomb
description:
Limestone slab, rectangular in shape, decorated with a sunk relief representation of three women mourning before a tomb. Only one of the women is completely preserved.
Condition: Left hand edge and upper right edge much chipped; other small chips. Paint missing; surface rubbed.
section: Preparing for and Sending to the Afterlife

museum_location.name: Funerary Gallery 2, Martha A. and Robert S. Rubin Gallery, 3rd Floor

completeness.name: Best
completeness.description: All data has been vetted. Objects generally have quality photos and descriptions.

labels.title: 37.1504E
labels.content: Members of the wealthier ranks hired professional mourners for their funeral rituals. These could include both women and men. In addition to performing stylized motions, they may have also sung or made other sounds during the funeral. The mourners in this relief are in the courtyard in front of a tomb entrance, represented on the right. This relief comes from a tomb, where it guaranteed perpetual mourning for the deceased.

collections.name: Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art

exhibitions.title: To Live Forever: Egyptian Treasures from the Brooklyn Museum
